name: 2-(1,2-dihydroacenaphthylen-5-yl)-3-phenylquinoxaline
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3221
Reason: 1,2-dihydroacenaphthylen-5-yl and phenyl groups both contribute to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, with an approximate increase of +20°C for each additional fused aromatic ring and +30°C for the methoxy group. The ketone group introduces polar carbonyl interactions, contributing approximately +40°C. The quinoxaline base itself has a melting point around 106°C. The presence of two additional phenyl groups linked in a linear fashion raises the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions and rigidity. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight.
